title: Autonomous Uncertainty Quantification for Computational Point-of-care Sensors
summary: This paper introduces an autonomous uncertainty quantification technique to improve the reliability of neural network-based computational point-of-care (POC) sensors. By integrating Monte Carlo dropout (MCDO) into a diagnostic pipeline for Lyme disease, the authors significantly enhanced diagnostic sensitivity and reliability by identifying and excluding erroneous, high-uncertainty predictions without needing ground truth data.

title: TICON: A Slide-Level Tile Contextualizer for Histopathology Representation Learning
summary: TICON is a novel transformer-based tile contextualizer designed to generate rich, context-aware embeddings from diverse tile-level foundation models in histopathology Whole Slide Images (WSI). It addresses the crucial need for slide-level contextual information by unifying and enhancing existing tile representations, leading to significant performance improvements across a wide array of computational pathology tasks. Notably, TICON enables the development of highly efficient slide-level foundation models that achieve state-of-the-art results with substantially less training data.

title: An Allele-Centric Pan-Graph-Matrix Representation for Scalable Pangenome Analysis
summary: This paper introduces H1 and H2, novel allele-centric and path-centric pangenome representations, respectively, designed for scalable analysis across large cohorts by unifying single-nucleotide and structural variations. These representations achieve substantial compression gains, particularly for structural variants, through adaptive per-allele compression, while maintaining exact information equivalence to traditional pangenome graphs.

title: Beyond Pixel Simulation: Pathology Image Generation via Diagnostic Semantic Tokens and Prototype Control
summary: UniPath is a novel semantics-driven framework for pathology image generation that overcomes the limitations of pixel-based simulation by integrating mature diagnostic understanding. It introduces Multi-Stream Control, leveraging Raw-Text, High-Level Semantics with Diagnostic Semantic Tokens, and Prototype control, achieving state-of-the-art performance in image quality and fine-grained semantic control while addressing data scarcity with new curated datasets.

title: zkFL-Health: Blockchain-Enabled Zero-Knowledge Federated Learning for Medical AI Privacy
summary: zkFL-Health introduces a novel architecture that integrates Federated Learning (FL) with Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs) and Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs) to overcome privacy and trust limitations in medical AI training. This framework enables verifiable, privacy-preserving collaborative AI development across multiple healthcare institutions by ensuring accurate model aggregation from committed client updates without revealing sensitive data. The system aims to provide robust confidentiality, integrity, and auditability crucial for clinical adoption and regulatory compliance.

title: Multi-Attribute guided Thermal Face Image Translation based on Latent Diffusion Model
summary: This paper introduces a novel latent diffusion-based model to address the challenges of Heterogeneous Face Recognition (HFR), specifically converting thermal infrared face images into high-quality visible light images for improved recognition accuracy. The model integrates a multi-attribute classifier to preserve critical identity features and a Self-attn Mamba module to enhance global cross-modal feature modeling and accelerate inference, achieving state-of-the-art performance in both image quality and identity preservation.

title: Learning from Neighbors with PHIBP: Predicting Infectious Disease Dynamics in Data-Sparse Environments
summary: This paper introduces the Poisson Hierarchical Indian Buffet Process (PHIBP) as a novel computational framework to accurately predict infectious disease outbreaks, particularly in geographic regions characterized by sparse or zero historical case data. By utilizing the concept of absolute abundance and borrowing statistical strength from related areas, PHIBP successfully generates robust predictive distributions and meaningful epidemiological insights, overcoming the inherent challenges of sparse count data that hinder traditional relative-rate methods.

title: A Blockchain-Monitored Agentic AI Architecture for Trusted Perception-Reasoning-Action Pipelines
summary: This paper proposes a novel architecture integrating a LangChain-based multi-agent AI system with a permissioned blockchain (Hyperledger Fabric) to ensure trusted, auditable, and policy-compliant autonomous decision-making. The framework monitors, verifies, and records the AI's perception-reasoning-action pipeline, demonstrating its effectiveness in critical applications like healthcare monitoring while maintaining operational efficiency. It aims to address concerns regarding trust, oversight, and integrity in agentic AI systems used for autonomous decisions.

title: Automatic Replication of LLM Mistakes in Medical Conversations
summary: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly evaluated in clinical settings using multi-dimensional rubrics which quantify reasoning quality, safety, and patient-centeredness. title: WSD-MIL: Window Scale Decay Multiple Instance Learning for Whole Slide Image Classification
summary: WSD-MIL proposes a novel Multiple Instance Learning (MIL) approach for Whole Slide Image (WSI) classification that addresses the limitations of existing Transformer-based methods regarding computational complexity and varying tumor scales. It introduces a window scale decay based attention module for efficient multi-scale local relationship modeling and a region gate module for enhanced global information, achieving state-of-the-art performance with significant memory reduction on cancer datasets.

title: HistoWAS: A Pathomics Framework for Large-Scale Feature-Wide Association Studies of Tissue Topology and Patient Outcomes
summary: HistoWAS is a novel computational framework designed to link intricate tissue spatial organization to patient clinical outcomes, addressing limitations in current pathomic analysis. It augments conventional feature sets with 30 topological and spatial features adapted from Geographic Information Systems (GIS) point pattern analysis, then employs a Phenome-Wide Association Study (PheWAS)-inspired engine to perform mass univariate regression. The framework's utility was demonstrated as a proof-of-concept on 385 PAS-stained Whole Slide Images (WSIs) from 206 participants in the Kidney Precision Medicine Project (KPMP).
